result.markdown:
--- title: "Solution to ggplot tasks" number-sections: true --- ## Getting started with ggplot and palmerpenguins ::: {.cell hash='ggplot_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-1_cd1e6d1cd0ef8b973711e97b5e5adc89'} ```{.r .cell-code} # install.packages("tidyverse") # install.packages("palmerpenguins") library(tidyverse) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` ── Attaching core tidyverse packages ──────────────────────── tidyverse 2.0.0 ── ✔ dplyr 1.1.2 ✔ readr 2.1.4 ✔ forcats 1.0.0 ✔ stringr 1.5.0 ✔ ggplot2 3.4.3 ✔ tibble 3.2.1 ✔ lubridate 1.9.2 ✔ tidyr 1.3.0 ✔ purrr 1.0.2 ── Conflicts ────────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse_conflicts() ── ✖ dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter() ✖ dplyr::lag() masks stats::lag() ℹ Use the conflicted package () to force all conflicts to become errors ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} library(palmerpenguins) ``` ::: - Have a look at the penguin data set ::: {.cell hash='ggplot_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-2_b2f5ee55cffe9a1c07f0032734e209ff'} ```{.r .cell-code} penguins ``` ::: ::: {.cell hash='ggplot_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-3_e806f07253b2c6181e9bf6a37e797724'} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 344 × 8 species island bill_length_mm bill_depth_mm flipper_length_mm body_mass_g 1 Adelie Torgersen 39.1 18.7 181 3750 2 Adelie Torgersen 39.5 17.4 186 3800 3 Adelie Torgersen 40.3 18 195 3250 4 Adelie Torgersen NA NA NA NA 5 Adelie Torgersen 36.7 19.3 193 3450 6 Adelie Torgersen 39.3 20.6 190 3650 # ℹ 338 more rows # ℹ 2 more variables: sex , year ``` ::: ::: ## Exploratory plotting ### Relationship between bill length and bill depth (scatterplot) What is the relationship between bill length and bill depth? - Create a scatterplot with bill length on the x-axis and bill depth on the y-axis - Can you add a regression line? - Add species as color aesthetic. Does your interpretation of the data change? - What is the difference between adding color as a global aesthetic or as a local aesthetic of the point layer? - Add species as shape aesthetic as well to distinguish the species ::: {.cell hash='ggplot_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-4_dcf66a166eef65d0d21a4cdf73fe2b6c'} ```{.r .cell-code} # Bill length vs. bill depth scatterplot with regression line ggplot( data = penguins, aes( x = bill_length_mm, y = bill_depth_mm ) ) + geom_point() + geom_smooth(method = "lm", se = FALSE) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` `geom_smooth()` using formula = 'y ~ x' ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` Warning: Removed 2 rows containing non-finite values (`stat_smooth()`). ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` Warning: Removed 2 rows containing missing values (`geom_point()`). ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](ggplot_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-4-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ::: {.cell hash='ggplot_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-5_a9418ed5aad3645935bdbe2ddde11568'} ```{.r .cell-code} # or short ggplot(penguins, aes(bill_length_mm, bill_depth_mm)) + geom_point() + geom_smooth(method = "lm", se = FALSE) ``` ::: If we add the color aesthetic locally to the point layer, only this layer will be affected by it. The regression line is not separated by species but still calculated and plotted for all data points together: ::: {.cell hash='ggplot_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-6_7068743d1330c3708dfc8bc211f0eff7'} ```{.r .cell-code} # Bill length vs. bill depth scatterplot with regression line # color as aesthetic local to the point layer ggplot(penguins, aes(bill_length_mm, bill_depth_mm)) + geom_point(aes(color = species)) + geom_smooth(method = "lm", se = FALSE) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` `geom_smooth()` using formula = 'y ~ x' ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` Warning: Removed 2 rows containing non-finite values (`stat_smooth()`). ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` Warning: Removed 2 rows containing missing values (`geom_point()`). ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](ggplot_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-6-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: We can see an example of the Simpson's paradox here. If you don't consider species, it looks like the bill depth decreases with bill length. But after separating the data by species, we see that the effect is actually the opposite. To draw separate regression lines for the species, we need to either add the color aesthetic to the smooth layer as well, or define the color aesthetic gloablly in the top layer `ggplot` call. ::: {.cell hash='ggplot_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-7_c337d5a2a8b608d3b9c1f8b21b5a2c91'} ```{.r .cell-code} # Option A: Define color aesthetic in smooth layer as well ggplot(penguins, aes(x = bill_length_mm, y = bill_depth_mm)) + geom_point(aes(color = species)) + geom_smooth(aes(color = species), method = "lm", se = FALSE ) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` `geom_smooth()` using formula = 'y ~ x' ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` Warning: Removed 2 rows containing non-finite values (`stat_smooth()`). ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` Warning: Removed 2 rows containing missing values (`geom_point()`). ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](ggplot_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-7-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ::: {.cell hash='ggplot_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-8_2a01cab6da50b4b6d166d0380fb36538'} ```{.r .cell-code} # Option B: Define color aesthetic once globally ggplot(penguins, aes( x = bill_length_mm, y = bill_depth_mm, color = species )) + geom_point() + geom_smooth(method = "lm", se = FALSE) ``` ::: ### Difference in flipper length between species (boxplot) Is there a difference in flipper length between the species? - Create a boxplot of the flipper length (y-axis) for the different species (x-axis) - Try adding notches to the boxplots by setting `notch = TRUE` in the boxplot layer - **Extra:** Add a layer with `geom_point()`. Try setting `position = position_jitter()` as argument in the point layer. What does it do? ::: {.cell hash='ggplot_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-9_e7712e86e6890ee5e518154a44a177a2'} ```{.r .cell-code} # Basic boxplot of flipper length with notches ggplot(penguins, aes(species, flipper_length_mm)) + geom_boxplot(notch = TRUE) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` Warning: Removed 2 rows containing non-finite values (`stat_boxplot()`). ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](ggplot_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-9-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: A `geom_point` with `position = position_jitter()` will add the individual data points to the plot. It's important to set a seed here to get the same result for the point position on the x-axis every time. Otherwise your plot is not reproducible. ::: {.cell hash='ggplot_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-10_73cc9115a41afa9646d541d323ea0c8e'} ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot(penguins, aes(species, flipper_length_mm)) + geom_boxplot() + geom_point(position = position_jitter(seed = 123)) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` Warning: Removed 2 rows containing non-finite values (`stat_boxplot()`). ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` Warning: Removed 2 rows containing missing values (`geom_point()`). ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](ggplot_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-10-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ### Differences between body mass of male and female penguins (boxplot) Are male penguins heavier than female penguins? And is this different between the 3 species? - Create a boxplot with body mass on the y axis and sex on the x axis - Add the difference between penguin species to this plot. Try the different options ggplot offers - species as color aesthetic - species as fill aesthetic - species as facet using `facet_wrap` - **Extra:** What happens if you use `geom_violin` instead of `geom_boxplot`? Can you combine both geoms in one plot? ::: {.cell hash='ggplot_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-11_ad05283f7d391abbc38e0bb0044073a2'} ```{.r .cell-code} # Basic boxplot of body mass for penguins of different sex ggplot(penguins, aes(x = sex, y = body_mass_g)) + geom_boxplot() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` Warning: Removed 2 rows containing non-finite values (`stat_boxplot()`). ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](ggplot_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-11-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: Species as color aesthetic: ::: {.cell hash='ggplot_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-12_581622e44eeedb344bce8ee0b7fb346d'} ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot(penguins, aes(x = sex, y = body_mass_g)) + geom_boxplot(aes(color = species)) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` Warning: Removed 2 rows containing non-finite values (`stat_boxplot()`). ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](ggplot_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-12-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: Species as fill aesthetic ::: {.cell hash='ggplot_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-13_1b066a8436f3126f9f2d2a531d557ba0'} ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot(penguins, aes(x = sex, y = body_mass_g)) + geom_boxplot(aes(fill = species)) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` Warning: Removed 2 rows containing non-finite values (`stat_boxplot()`). ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](ggplot_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-13-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: Species as facets: ::: {.cell hash='ggplot_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-14_7e834977a27b96f9116502d6515d2d76'} ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot(penguins, aes(x = sex, y = body_mass_g)) + geom_boxplot() + facet_wrap(~species) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` Warning: Removed 2 rows containing non-finite values (`stat_boxplot()`). ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](ggplot_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-14-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: With geom_violin ::: {.cell hash='ggplot_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-15_5ce80550980c5d1f672a9a9467de73bd'} ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot(penguins, aes(x = sex, y = body_mass_g)) + geom_violin() + geom_boxplot(width = .4) + facet_wrap(~species) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` Warning: Removed 2 rows containing non-finite values (`stat_ydensity()`). ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` Warning: Removed 2 rows containing non-finite values (`stat_boxplot()`). ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](ggplot_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-15-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ### Distribution of flipper length between species (histogram) Make a histogram of the the flipper length separated by species. Try different methods of separating the species (color or facet). Compare stacked and overlapping histograms. Stacked histogram (default position is `"stacked"`) ::: {.cell hash='ggplot_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-16_4f3f20ae7ad56939d38be3d726cd3da3'} ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot(penguins, aes( x = flipper_length_mm, fill = species )) + geom_histogram() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` `stat_bin()` using `bins = 30`. Pick better value with `binwidth`. ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` Warning: Removed 2 rows containing non-finite values (`stat_bin()`). ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](ggplot_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-16-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: Overlapping histogram ::: {.cell hash='ggplot_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-17_5603c96858eb8c0531ddb583dd1d1776'} ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot(penguins, aes( x = flipper_length_mm, fill = species )) + geom_histogram( alpha = 0.5, position = "identity" ) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` `stat_bin()` using `bins = 30`. Pick better value with `binwidth`. ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` Warning: Removed 2 rows containing non-finite values (`stat_bin()`). ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](ggplot_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-17-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: Separated by facets (no need to specify the position because only one group per plot): ::: {.cell hash='ggplot_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-18_e7871f8b33e282bda7bdf45b245b00b5'} ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot(penguins, aes( x = flipper_length_mm, fill = species )) + geom_histogram() + facet_wrap(~species, scales = "free_x", ncol = 1) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` `stat_bin()` using `bins = 30`. Pick better value with `binwidth`. ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` Warning: Removed 2 rows containing non-finite values (`stat_bin()`). ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](ggplot_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-18-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ### Penguin flipper length by species and sex (heatmap) Create a heat map that shows: - The categories sex and species on x- and y-axis - The flipper length as color For this data it does not make too much sense, but a heat map would look like this: ::: {.cell hash='ggplot_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-19_fdf9f661fa2c160c8abb362bbf55ccb7'} ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot(penguins, aes( x = species, y = sex, fill = flipper_length_mm )) + geom_tile() ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](ggplot_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-19-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ## Beautify the plots ### Beatuify plots from 1.3 Here are just some examples of how to make the plots from before prettier. Of course there a many other options as well. **Example one: Boxplot of flipper length and species** ::: {.cell hash='ggplot_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-20_4adfca0373dd1cf78cdba0c35a5528f8'} ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot(penguins, aes(species, flipper_length_mm, color = species)) + geom_boxplot(width = 0.3) + geom_point( alpha = 0.5, position = position_jitter(width = 0.1, seed = 123) ) + ggsci::scale_color_uchicago() + labs(x = "Species", y = "Flipper length (mm)") + theme_minimal() + theme(legend.position = "none") ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` Warning: Removed 2 rows containing non-finite values (`stat_boxplot()`). ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` Warning: Removed 2 rows containing missing values (`geom_point()`). ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](ggplot_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-20-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: What was changed compared to the basic plot? - Add color for each species by setting a global `color` aesthetic - Make boxes and jitter points less wide by setting `width` for both layers - Make jitter points slightly transparent by specifying `alpha = 0.5` for the jitter layer - Change the color to nicer colors from the `ggsci` package - Change from default theme to `theme_minimal()` - Remove the legend with `legend.position = "none"` - Change the axis labels with `labs()` **Example two: Reproducing the plot from the presentation** The following code is adapted from the [palmerpengins package website](https://allisonhorst.github.io/palmerpenguins/articles/examples.html). ::: {.cell hash='ggplot_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-21_619f350a8cfca83891f9ea91a62952e5'} ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot( data = penguins, aes( x = bill_length_mm, y = bill_depth_mm, color = species, shape = species ) ) + geom_point(size = 3, alpha = 0.8) + geom_smooth(method = "lm", se = FALSE) + scale_color_manual(values = c("darkorange", "purple", "cyan4")) + labs( title = "Penguin bill dimensions", subtitle = "Bill length and depth for Adelie, Chinstrap and Gentoo Penguins at Palmer Station LTER", x = "Bill length (mm)", y = "Bill depth (mm)", color = "Penguin species", shape = "Penguin species" ) + theme_minimal() + theme( legend.position = c(0.85, 0.15), legend.background = element_rect(fill = "white", color = NA) ) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` `geom_smooth()` using formula = 'y ~ x' ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` Warning: Removed 2 rows containing non-finite values (`stat_smooth()`). ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` Warning: Removed 2 rows containing missing values (`geom_point()`). ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](ggplot_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-21-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: What was changed compared to the basic plot? - Make points larger and slightly transparent by setting `size` and `alpha` for the point layer - Change to custom color scale - Add title and subtitle with `labs` - Change title of x-axis, y-axis and legend for color and shape aesthetic with `labs` - Use `theme_minimal()` instead of default theme - Change legend position to bottom right corner within the plot - Positions are relative to the bottom left corner of the plot - 0.85 (85% of plot width) to the right - 0.15 (15% of plot height) towards the top ## Save one of the plots on your machine Example with one of the plots from above: ::: {.cell hash='ggplot_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-22_23fbce74b9130eb44aa514d7c8a94972'} ```{.r .cell-code} flipper_box <- ggplot(penguins, aes(species, flipper_length_mm, color = species)) + geom_boxplot(width = 0.3) + geom_jitter(alpha = 0.5, position = position_jitter(width = 0.2, seed = 123)) + ggsci::scale_color_uchicago() + labs(x = "Species", y = "Flipper length (mm)") + theme_minimal() + theme(legend.position = "none") ``` ::: ::: {.cell hash='ggplot_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-23_37ceeb902e3366eda184dfd2576adfe4'} ```{.r .cell-code} # save as png in /img directory of the project ggsave(filename = "./img/flipper_box.png", flipper_box) # save as pdf in /img directory of the project ggsave(filename = "./img/flipper_box.pdf", flipper_box) ``` ::: ## Some more examples **Histogram** ::: {.cell hash='ggplot_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-24_9319e8f8d57c9c43a35b571405abc321'} ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot(penguins, aes(x = flipper_length_mm, fill = species)) + geom_histogram(alpha = 0.6) + ggsci::scale_fill_d3() + labs( y = "Frequency", x = "Flipper length [mm]", fill = "Penguin species" ) + theme_minimal() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` `stat_bin()` using `bins = 30`. Pick better value with `binwidth`. ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` Warning: Removed 2 rows containing non-finite values (`stat_bin()`). ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](ggplot_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-24-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: **Heat map** For the penguin data set a heat map does not make that much sense. But an example would be: ::: {.cell hash='ggplot_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-25_9d61bf8d8e441d8b4979ee6da28c7b6f'} ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot(penguins, aes( x = species, y = sex, fill = flipper_length_mm )) + geom_tile() + scale_fill_viridis_c() + theme_classic() ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](ggplot_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-25-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ### The `plotly` package You can use the `plotly package` to create interactive plots where you can e.g. hover over an area of your plot with the mouse and the respective values will be displayed. To get started, you have to install the plotly package ::: {.cell hash='ggplot_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-26_3f676af14c7921b656498db5f204e88e'} ```{.r .cell-code} install.packages("plotly") ``` ::: You can use any ggplot and wrap it in the `ggplotly` function from the `plotly` package to make it interactive, e.g. ::: {.cell hash='ggplot_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-27_ade9f57c042474d23ad92f0640b0289d'} ```{.r .cell-code} plotly::ggplotly(flipper_box) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` Warning: Removed 2 rows containing non-finite values (`stat_boxplot()`). ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}
``` ::: ::: ### The `patchwork` package With the `patchwork` package, you can combine multiple ggplots into one plot. The package allows you to add annotations to the plot and to control the layout and appearance. Below you find a simple example of two different penugin scatterplots. For more explanation and an overview of what is possible with the package, please have a look at the [package documentation](https://patchwork.data-imaginist.com/) ::: {.cell hash='ggplot_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-28_6e4df704f1dde6db2e62420559e5974a'} ```{.r .cell-code} # library(patchwork) # # Collecting legends and defining a common theme # plot_1 <- ggplot(penguins, aes( # x = bill_length_mm, y = bill_depth_mm, # color = species # )) + # geom_point() # # plot_2 <- ggplot(penguins, aes( # x = bill_length_mm, y = body_mass_g, # color = species # )) + # geom_point() # # # Simple combination of 2 plots in patchwork # plot_1 + plot_2 # # # more complex combination with annotation and definition of shared layers # final_plot <- plot_1 + plot_2 + # plot_layout(guides = "collect") + # plot_annotation(tag_levels = "a", tag_prefix = "(", tag_suffix = ")") & # theme_minimal() & # scale_color_manual(values = c("darkorange", "purple", "cyan4")) & # labs( # color = "Penguin species" # ) & # theme( # plot.tag.position = c(0.1, 0.95), # plot.tag = element_text(face = "bold") # ) ``` ::: ## References Check out the [package website](https://allisonhorst.github.io/palmerpenguins/articles/examples.html) of the `palmerpenguin` package. They have more nice examples of data visualizations that you can do with ggplot. Horst AM, Hill AP, Gorman KB (2020). palmerpenguins: Palmer Archipelago (Antarctica) penguin data. R package version 0.1.0. https://allisonhorst.github.io/palmerpenguins/. doi: 10.5281/zenodo.3960218.
